semantic_title: Encounter for Full Term Uncomplicated Delivery - Code O80
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 15. Pregnancy, Childbirth, and the Puerperium > n. Normal Delivery, Code O80 > 1) Encounter for full term uncomplicated delivery

content.full_text: Code O80 should be assigned when a patient is admitted for a full-term normal delivery and delivers a single, healthy infant without any complications antepartum, during the delivery, or postpartum during the delivery episode. Code O80 is always a principal diagnosis. It is not to be used if any other code from chapter 15 is needed to describe a current complication of the antenatal, delivery, or postnatal period. Additional codes from other chapters may be used with code O80 if they are not related to or are in any way complicating the pregnancy. (Evidence: pg no: 69, L70-L76)
content.summary: Strict criteria for using O80 code for uncomplicated deliveries including exclusions and additional coding rules (Evidence: pg no: 69, L70-L76)
key_concepts: Full-term normal delivery criteria (Evidence: pg no: 69, L70-L72)
O80 always principal diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 69, L74)
No Chapter 15 complications allowed (Evidence: pg no: 69, L74-L76)
Non-pregnancy related codes permitted (Evidence: pg no: 69, L75-L76)

detailed_rules.rule_text: O80 requires full-term normal delivery of single, healthy infant without complications (Evidence: pg no: 69, L70-L72)
detailed_rules.explanation: Code O80 has strict criteria: must be full-term, normal delivery, single infant, healthy infant, and no complications during any phase (Evidence: pg no: 69, L70-L72)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code O80 is always a principal diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 69, L74)
detailed_rules.explanation: When O80 is used, it must be the principal diagnosis and cannot be secondary (Evidence: pg no: 69, L74)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Do not use O80 if any other Chapter 15 code is needed for current complications (Evidence: pg no: 69, L74-L76)
detailed_rules.explanation: Any current pregnancy, delivery, or postpartum complication requiring a Chapter 15 code excludes the use of O80 (Evidence: pg no: 69, L74-L76)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Additional codes from other chapters may be used if not pregnancy-related (Evidence: pg no: 69, L75-L76)
detailed_rules.explanation: Non-pregnancy related conditions can be coded with O80 as long as they don't complicate the pregnancy (Evidence: pg no: 69, L75-L76)

workflow_steps: Step 3: Ensure no complications antepartum, during delivery, or postpartum
Step 4: Verify no Chapter 15 codes needed
Step 5: Assign O80 as principal diagnosis
Step 6: Add non-pregnancy related codes if applicable

specific_codes.description: Encounter for full term uncomplicated delivery (Evidence: pg no: 69, L70)

breakdown.80: Encounter for full term uncomplicated delivery

code_categories_mentioned: Chapter 15 - Pregnancy, childbirth and the puerperium

coding_scenarios.documentation_example: 28-year-old female delivered a healthy full-term infant vaginally without complications
step_by_step: Step 2: Confirm single, healthy infant - yes
Step 4: Assign O80 as principal diagnosis

correct_coding.rationale: Meets all criteria for uncomplicated delivery (Evidence: pg no: 69, L70-L76)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Cannot use O80 with any other Chapter 15 codes
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Adding pregnancy complication codes with O80

warnings: O80 is always principal diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 69, L74)
Cannot use with any other Chapter 15 codes (Evidence: pg no: 69, L74-L76)
best_practices: Verify all criteria before using O80 (Evidence: pg no: 69, L70-L72)
Only add non-pregnancy related codes (Evidence: pg no: 69, L75-L76)
tips: O80 is very restrictive - any complication excludes its use
implementation_notes: Must be truly uncomplicated throughout entire episode
clinical_context: Reserved for completely normal, uncomplicated deliveries
